postItText: • Diversity numbers in companies, job/unemployment rate, tech skills gap narrowing
• Percent of people earning a living wage in a community increases
• Measure changes in community economic health when a large influx of high tech jobs grow in a community
• Reduced dependency on social services in communities that increase computing jobs
• Tracking women and minorities employed in local CS companies
• Reduction in number of open/unfilled engineering and programming positions
• Tracking social mobility of current CS graduates
• Increase in non-traditional students and non-traditional pathways in workforce
• % of URMs passing the AP
• Reform hiring criteria to maximize diverse talent
• Increase in number of historically underrepresented groups in workforce
• % / # of URM in computing increases proportions
• Closing/Narrowing the gap in the shortage of engineers and programmers with a diverse workforce

category: Support Tech Companies and Tech Employees
postItText: • Number of tech companies in El Paso increases
• Increase in number of job offers for new graduates (at UTEP)
• Increase in computing jobs attained by those reviewing computing credentials
• Texans are filling the jobs in engineering and programming
• Retention of URMs in computing professions increases
• Increased rates of volunteering/engagement with community
• Community reciprocal engagement with students
• How culturally responsive computing can engage students in local community?

category: Rights and Responsibilities to participate in democracy
postItText: • Justify ethical choices in digital life
• Students are able to ask informed questions about how their tech use impacts society and how societal tech impacts various populations
• Student ability to argue about impacts on democracy of tech
• Students are aware of the responsibilities as creators of technology to society
• % of students registering to vote & % of students (citizens) voting
• Students can explain impacts of technology across different groups/cultures/demographics
• Increased..... rate.... (es.....
• Students have agency in using and creating tech for societal (community) problems
• Student understanding of tech in society --> ways it's used and how to use it back
• Students are aware of dangers to democracy from technology
• Students understanding of algorithms in social networks
• Awareness of a core set of issues (tbd) and how a lack of awareness leads to inequitable outcomes
• Increased desire to pursue civically oriented pursuits
• Students can design technology solutions to solve local problems
• Student self-efficacy and feelings of being able to impact society
• How students use CS to solve local civic issues?
• Students can navigate the positive opportunities and ethical challenges of digital life.
• Affect towards citizenship and civic engagement as it pertains to CS and society
• More (and more diverse) students run for public office
• Increase the number of underrepresented individuals who vote
• More (and more diverse) students vote
• Increase the rate of voter turnout and participation in local and national elections
• Seeing more young people question platforms and systems put into place
• ....startups with a double-bottom line
• Increase the number of community engagement projects by schools/districts
• Increase the number of community-based integrations in CS (consensible?)...
• Success in working in a diverse group environment
• Do CS outside of classroom
• Evaluation: long-term tracking
• Outcomes
• Student voices at the end of programs and projects would reflect intended outcomes (Ex: I learned to collaborate by XX because YY.)
• What is the right amount of exposure to CT (all or 1 of 7) strategies to become proficient?
• Ability to problem-solve across curriculum/content
• Successful demographics
• Who are the A students? The C students? The D, F students?
• % increase of Latinx/Black/Native youth participating/applying for competitions and awards in CS (i.e. NCWIT, First, etc.)
• % increase of girls participating in entrepreneurship/innovation competitions
• Clear teacher pathways are identified for High School educators; certification process available across states
• Heat map of people with CS skills (does it span communities)
• Increase in # of companies addressing wicked problems
• Concept map of wicked problems & potential solutions
• Number of CS patents to solve CS problems
• Number of new innovations produced with CS
• Increase in the number of CS+X programs across all major disciplinary areas (STEM, humanities, social sciences)
• Increase in the number of curricula that integrate CS and other disciplines
• All K-5 teachers receive CS or CT education via pre-service courses within social justice education framework
• CS-related projects that are helping to solve a community-identified problem
• Number of (or %) communities impacted by a locally CS-solved problem & represented --> which ones
• More teachers of color in CS education
• Does faculty reflect community?
• Are students with disabilities included in CS classes?
• Proportion of CS students enrolled in CS courses who are female, low income, URM, disabled (participation)
• Does representation in the classroom = representation in the community?
• Indicators of student engagement, identity, agency, especially underrepresented students
• Increasing teacher participation
• Every CS PD work with teachers around equity, biases
• Proportion of CS teachers in low income, high-URM population areas who are qualified to teach CS (quality)
• # of faculty who attend PD on incorporating social justice in the curriculum
• Use of curriculum that includes inquiry-based units learning about social justice
• In teaching programming are accessible tools used?
• Does web design/dev course include accessible design?
• Pathways in ED: CTE vs. Academic
• Simplifying language on how we communicate about CS education to the uninformed
• Changing the way we develop CS curriculum making it more adaptable based on student feedback
• Are ethics, equity, and cultural sensitivity in the curriculum?
• Are CS projects reflecting the needs of the community?
• % of Projects with other more/less fortunate communities
• CS projects in community?
• Proportion of schools that offer CS that are in areas of low income, rural, high URM population (access)
• Identifying diversity of iniquities cross culturally and not only based on socio economic or minority status
• Change in attitudes in students around social justice before the course and after the courses
• Increasing mentorships for students and faculty
• Kids are creating individually meaningful projects
• Students being exposed to projects that promote collaboration and creativity
• Teachers in post surveys report students to appear engaged and interested in lessons and activities
• Administrators and other family members report teaches and students (children) are engaged by CS/CT coursework
• Students in post-course/club survey report being engaged and empowered by curricula and activities
• Kids feel they can express themselves through CS practices and concepts
• Research in how students are able to express themselves through CS activities
• Students rank favorite courses at their school in terms of autonomy and engagement
• Student recommendation rate (would you recommend this course/club/etc. to a friend?)
• Inter-group parity in self-described affective happiness measures (diability cs. mainstream; ethnicity; gender)
